"**Red Red Wine** " is a song originally written, performed, and recorded by
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States") singer [Neil
Diamond](/wiki/Neil_Diamond "Neil Diamond") in 1967. It is included on Neil's
second studio album, _[Just for You](/wiki/Just_for_You_\(Neil_Diamond_album\)
"Just for You \(Neil Diamond album\)")_. The lyrics are sung from the
perspective of a person who finds that drinking [red wine](/wiki/Red_wine "Red
wine") is the only way to forget his woes.

When Neil left the [Bang Records](/wiki/Bang_Records "Bang Records") label in
1968, Bang continued to release Neil Diamond singles, often adding newly
recorded instruments and background vocals to album tracks from the two Neil
Diamond albums that Bang had issued. For the "Red Red Wine" single, Bang added
a background choir without Neil's involvement or permission. Diamond's version
reached number sixty-two on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100
"Billboard Hot 100") chart in 1968. A live version was released on Diamond's
_The Greatest Hits (1966–92)_ but the 1968 single version has never been
issued on a vinyl album or CD.

The song was covered by several artists shortly after Diamond's recording was
released. In 1968, the Dutch singer [Peter Tetteroo](/wiki/Peter_Tetteroo
"Peter Tetteroo") (from the band [Tee Set](/wiki/Tee_Set "Tee Set")) had a hit
with a cover of the song in [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands").
[Tony Tribe](/wiki/Tony_Tribe "Tony Tribe") covered the song in 1969 in a
[reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae")-influenced style. In 1983, [UB40](/wiki/UB40
"UB40") recorded perhaps the best known version of the song, in a lighter
reggae style. The UB40 version topped the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") and the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"). Diamond later performed a
UB40-inspired version of the song while on tour.

[UB40](/wiki/UB40 "UB40") recorded their rendition for their album of [cover
versions](/wiki/Cover_versions "Cover versions"), _[Labour of
Love](/wiki/Labour_of_Love "Labour of Love")_. According to the band, they
were only familiar with Tony Tribe's version (they apparently didn't realise
that the writer, credited simply as "Diamond", was in fact Neil Diamond), and
their version featured a lighter, [reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae")-style flavor
compared to Diamond's somber, [acoustic](/wiki/Acoustic_music "Acoustic
music") [ballad](/wiki/Ballad "Ballad"). The UB40 version adds a
[toasted](/wiki/Deejay_\(Jamaican\) "Deejay \(Jamaican\)") verse by UB40
member [Astro](/wiki/Astro_\(UB40\) "Astro \(UB40\)"), opening: "Red Red Wine,
you make me feel so fine/You keep me rocking all of the time", which was
edited from the single that reached [number one](/wiki/Chart-topper "Chart-
topper") on the UK Singles Chart in August 1983 and number 34 in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") in March 1984 but not from the
version that reached number one on the _Billboard_ Hot 100 a few months after
being performed at the [Nelson Mandela 70th Birthday
Concert](/wiki/Nelson_Mandela_70th_Birthday_Tribute "Nelson Mandela 70th
Birthday Tribute") in 1988. In September 2014, the [Official Charts
Company](/wiki/Official_Charts_Company "Official Charts Company") announced
that sales in the UK had reached one million.[1]

Songwriter Neil Diamond has stated that it is one of his favorite covers of
his songs.[2] Diamond frequently performs the song live using the UB40 reggae
arrangement as opposed to the original version.

## Other cover
songs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red_Red_Wine&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Other cover songs")]

Swedish group Tom & Mick & Maniacs released their version of the song in 1967.
This appears to be the first recorded version of the song.

[Jimmy James and The Vagabonds](/wiki/Jimmy_James_\(singer\) "Jimmy James
\(singer\)") released a [cover version](/wiki/Cover_version "Cover version")
the same year as Diamond's version (1968), for the [UK](/wiki/United_Kingdom
"United Kingdom") market. It charted at number thirty-six.

In 1968, singer Peter Tetteroo, of Dutch beat group Tee Set, released a cover
version that reached number six on the Dutch top-40 chart.

[Tony Tribe](/wiki/Tony_Tribe "Tony Tribe"), a Jamaican singer, recorded a
[reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae")-influenced version in 1969 which reached
number forty-six on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles
Chart"),[19] this became [Trojan Records](/wiki/Trojan_Records "Trojan
Records") first chart hit[20] and has been included in numerous reggae
compilations since. The song was also covered in 1969 by singer [Charles
Mann](/wiki/Charles_Mann_\(singer\) "Charles Mann \(singer\)").

In 1970, a remake by [Vic Dana](/wiki/Vic_Dana "Vic Dana") became a minor
_Billboard_ Hot 100 hit, peaking at number 72 and reached number 30 on the
Adult Contemporary chart. In early 1972, singer [Roy Drusky](/wiki/Roy_Drusky
"Roy Drusky") enjoyed a top 20 hit with his version, reaching number 17 on the
_Billboard_ Hot Country Songs chart and number 16 on the Canada Country chart.

Mexican ballad band [Los
Rehenes](/w/index.php?title=Los_Rehenes&action=edit&redlink=1 "Los Rehenes
\(page does not exist\)") recorded a Spanish version named _Vino Tinto_ (lit.
Red Wine).

[The Hobos](/wiki/The_Hobos "The Hobos") included the song on their 2004
double studio album, _[Radio Jah Jah](/wiki/Radio_Jah_Jah "Radio Jah Jah")_.
"Red Red Wine" was also performed by Peter Tetteroo, former singer of [Tee
Set](/wiki/Tee_Set "Tee Set"), a Dutch band, in 1968. The song has also been
performed by [Cas Haley](/wiki/Cas_Haley "Cas Haley") along with UB40 on the
last episode of the season two show _[America's Got
Talent](/wiki/America%27s_Got_Talent "America's Got Talent")_.

In 2001, singer [Elan Atias](/wiki/Elan_Atias "Elan Atias") released a
[dancehall](/wiki/Dancehall "Dancehall") version on the _Buy Out Riddim_
instrumental, best known performed by [Sean Paul](/wiki/Sean_Paul "Sean
Paul"), with the song entitled, "[Like Glue](/wiki/Like_Glue "Like Glue")".
This was the first time the song was performed on a totally different
[instrumental](/wiki/Instrumental "Instrumental") tracking. The lyrics were
also re-written. In 2008, [Sizzla](/wiki/Sizzla "Sizzla") also released a
dancehall single ("No Time To Gaze") based on the UB40 version.

In March 2017, [Andrew Bogut](/wiki/Andrew_Bogut "Andrew Bogut") posted the
UB40 version on his Twitter[21] to signify he was joining the [Cleveland
Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") – the team's
colours include the darkish red "wine".
